sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content:
The Music.PlayFileReturn procedure is used to play a file of music. The file must be in one of the acceptable formats and the machine, must have the appropriate hardware.

The fileNameparameter must give the format of the file:

  WAV files   "WAV:filename" or "filename.WAV"
  MP3 files   "MP3:filename" or "filename.MP3"
  MIDI files   "MIDI:filename" or "filename.MIDI"

Unlike Music.PlayFile, the Music.PlayFileReturn procedure should not be called in a separate process. Instead, the procedure returns immediately. This makes Music.PlayFileReturn easier to use, but makes it unsuitable for playing a set of files sequentially.
sections.text_content:
The Music.PlayFileReturn procedure is used to play a file of music. The file must be in one of the acceptable formats and the machine, must have the appropriate hardware.
The fileNameparameter must give the format of the file:
 WAV files "WAV:filename" or "filename.WAV" MP3 files "MP3:filename" or "filename.MP3" MIDI files "MIDI:filename" or "filename.MIDI"
Unlike Music.PlayFile, the Music.PlayFileReturn procedure should not be called in a 
separate process. Instead, the procedure returns immediately. This makes Music.PlayFileReturn
easier to use, but makes it unsuitable for playing a set of files sequentially.
sections.mdown_content:
The **Music.PlayFileReturn** procedure is used to play a file of music. The file must be in one of the acceptable formats and the machine, must have the appropriate hardware.
The *fileName*parameter must give the format of the file:
 WAV files "WAV:filename" or "filename.WAV" MP3 files "MP3:filename" or "filename.MP3" MIDI files "MIDI:filename" or "filename.MIDI"
Unlike **Music.PlayFile**, the **Music.PlayFileReturn** procedure should not be called in a separate process. Instead, the procedure returns immediately. This makes **Music.PlayFileReturn**easier to use, but makes it unsuitable for playing a set of files sequentially.

sections.title: Example
code:
Music.PlayFileReturn ("branden3.wav")
        var x, y, clr : int
        loop
            x := Rand.Int (0, maxx)
            y := Rand.Int (0, maxy)
            clr := Rand.Int (0, maxcolor)
            Draw.FillOval (x, y, 30, 30, clr)
            exit when hasch
        end loop
        Music.PlayFileStop
sections.raw_content: This program plays the music in the file "branden3.wav" once while drawing ovals on the screen. If the music has not finished when the user presses a key, it is halted using Music.PlayFileStop
sections.text_content:
This program plays the music in the file "branden3.wav" once while drawing ovals on the screen.
If the music has not finished when the user presses a key, it is halted using Music.PlayFileStop
sections.mdown_content: This program plays the music in the file "*branden3.wav*" once while drawing ovals on the screen.If the music has not finished when the user presses a key, it is halted using **Music.PlayFileStop**

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: To play a sound file requires that the computer be equipped with a sound card and speakers.
sections.text_content: To play a sound file requires that the computer be equipped with a sound card and speakers.
sections.mdown_content: To play a sound file requires that the computer be equipped with a sound card and speakers.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: The Turing 4.1 software can play files in the following audio formats: WAVE (.wav) files, MIDI files (.midi or .mid), and MP3 files (.mp3). In general, MIDI files are the most efficient and thus are the preferred form for longer music pieces like background music. WAVE files can record anything, not just music, so are often used for sound effects.
sections.text_content: The Turing 4.1 software can play files in the following audio formats: WAVE (.wav) files, MIDI files (.midi or .mid), and MP3 files (.mp3). In general, MIDI files are the most efficient and thus are the preferred form for longer music pieces like background music. WAVE files can record anything, not just music, so are often used for sound effects.
sections.mdown_content: The Turing 4.1 software can play files in the following audio formats: WAVE (.wav) files, MIDI files (.midi or .mid), and MP3 files (.mp3). In general, MIDI files are the most efficient and thus are the preferred form for longer music pieces like background music. WAVE files can record anything, not just music, so are often used for sound effects.

sections.title: Details
code:
Music.PlayFileReturn ("cd")       % Play the entire CD
        Music.PlayFileReturn ("cd:3")     % Play the third track on the CD
sections.raw_content: The Turing 4.1 software can also play music on a compact disk. Toplay the complete contents of the compact disk, the filename is “cd”. To play a single track from a compact disk, the filename is “cd:[track number]”.
sections.text_content: The Turing 4.1 software can also play music on a compact disk. Toplay the complete contents of the compact disk, the filename is cd. To play a single track from a compact disk, the filename is cd:[track number].
sections.mdown_content: The Turing 4.1 software can also play music on a compact disk. Toplay the complete contents of the compact disk, the filename is cd. To play a single track from a compact disk, the filename is cd:[track number].

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: On the PC, different formats of music can play simultaneously. This means that a program might use a MIDI file as a background soundtrack and then use WAVE files for individual sound effects. The sound effects would not interfere with the background music. Playing a second music file with the same format as an already playing piece immediately halts the first piece and starts the second. This can be used to stop a single type of music by playing a short silent piece of music.
sections.text_content: On the PC, different formats of music can play simultaneously. This means that a program might use a MIDI file as a background soundtrack and then use WAVE files for individual sound effects. The sound effects would not interfere with the background music. Playing a second music file with the same format as an already playing piece immediately halts the first piece and starts the second.  This can be used to stop a single type of music by playing a short silent piece of music.
sections.mdown_content: On the PC, different formats of music can play simultaneously. This means that a program might use a MIDI file as a background soundtrack and then use WAVE files for individual sound effects. The sound effects would not interfere with the background music. Playing a second music file with the same format as an already playing piece immediately halts the first piece and starts the second.  This can be used to stop a single type of music by playing a short silent piece of music.

sections.title: Example
code:
const STAR_SIZE : int := 80
        var pic, x, y, dx, dy : int
        
        % Get the original picture
        Draw.FillStar (3, 3, STAR_SIZE - 3, STAR_SIZE - 3, brightred)
        pic := Pic.New (0, 0, STAR_SIZE, STAR_SIZE)
        cls
        
        % Set the initial location and direction of movement
        x := Rand.Int (0, maxx - STAR_SIZE)
        y := Rand.Int (0, maxy - STAR_SIZE)
        dx := 1
        dy := 1
        
        Music.PlayFileLoop ("background.mid") % Start background music playing
        
        loop
            if x + dx < 0 or x + dx > maxx - STAR_SIZE then
                dx := -dx
                Music.PlayFileReturn ("boing.wav")
            end if
            if y + dy < 0 or y + dy > maxy - STAR_SIZE then
                dy := -dy
                Music.PlayFileReturn ("boing.wav")
            end if
            x += dx
            y += dy
            Pic.Draw (pic, x, y, picCopy)
            exit when hasch
            Time.Delay (5)
        end loop
        
        % Stop the background music.
        Music.PlayFileStop
sections.raw_content: This program bounces a maple leaf around the screen with background music and a sound effect when the maple leaf hits an edge. When the user presses any key, the program immediately exits.
sections.text_content: This program bounces a maple leaf around the screen with background music and a sound effect when the maple leaf hits an edge. When the user presses any key, the program immediately exits.
sections.mdown_content: This program bounces a maple leaf around the screen with background music and a sound effect when the maple leaf hits an edge. When the user presses any key, the program immediately exits.

sections.title: See also
sections.raw_content: Music.PlayFileStop to halt a music file that is current playing.
sections.text_content: Music.PlayFileStop to halt a music file that is current playing.

sections.title: Status
sections.raw_content:
Exported qualified.

This means that you can only call the function by calling Music.PlayFileReturn, not by calling PlayFileReturn.
sections.text_content:
Exported qualified.
This means that you can only call the function by calling Music.PlayFileReturn, not by calling PlayFileReturn.
sections.mdown_content:
Exported qualified.
This means that you can only call the function by calling **Music.PlayFileReturn**, not by calling **PlayFileReturn**.
